I can never decide whether I love everyone or hate them. Sometimes whatever people say or do is interesting, mainly for the reason behind whatever they've said or done. Other times it's more a case of "WHAT" or "REALLY?" I was exhausted today so there was a lot of the latter going on. In fact, it probably has very little to do with the people themselves, it's All About Me, as always. I feel like I'm going through about a year's worth of deja vu from my last university experience. The stuff we're being taught is really interesting most of the time, but I'm still doing the bare minimum work outside uni. My essay remains unfinished - the first draft deadline is tomorrow and the final draft next Friday. I'm aiming for a C. And I haven't been sleeping again, which is extremely frustrating and leads to a whole load of other things - lack of concentration, irritability, general slacking off. It all just feels a little too familiar. I'm nowhere near panic stage, and still fairly near the top of the Spiral of Misery, but I just wish I didn't have to make things so hard for myself all the damn time.

I have been lurking around these parts a lot lately, but haven't had much to say myself. One of my friends mentioned recently he had a blog and I just know it's about ASPs and FTPS and formatting and how rubbish some new obscure (i.e. non-Windows) software is because it doesn't allow for such and such formatting/convergence/processing something-or-other. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but it just would never occur to me to write so much about so little. I notice no small details whatsoever in my life, to the point where after watching a film I can't think of a single thing to say about it besides "that was good/bad/boring/weird". If anyone asks a follow up question like "why?" I'm way out of my depth. My style is more saying very little about quite big things (to me). My dad moved out. My nursing course is ok. My moods have been up and down.

And now for little bit of gap filling. I'm a terrible writer I know - I have this need to express things but at the same time don't really want to tell anyone anything. In conversations I go on about countless irrelevancies, only touching on what I really wanted to talk about for the briefest of moments, then wonder I'm left feeling unsatisfied. And here I am wondering now if even that's too much information. But back to the gap filling. Regarding unis, I basically chose neither and was marked down as withdrawn by default. About a week later I got a phonecall asking if I did this on purpose, because their systems had processed it a day early. So I explained and the woman said I could switch branches and I did, just like that. Pretty lucky really, and so far it feels like the right choice. Give it a couple of weeks though, when I'm on placement, which I'm pretty much terrified about. Real patients! Real lives! Real responsibities! But back to the gap filling. I carried on with my job until 2 weeks before the course started, going on holiday in early July. I went with a couple of friends to Poland and Austria (and Slovakia, but the less said about that the better), and it was really really good. Eleanor of course came back from uni, which was also good, but make sleeping arrangements increasingly difficult, particularly when her boyfriend was staying over. For a very long, aggravating time it was never explained to her why my mum was sleeping in my room, which I found incredibly frustrating and a huge strain. It was sort of like a "don't ask, don't tell" policy, and we all know how stupid that is. Eventually Eleanor asked me, and I was forced to tell her all the stuff that should've been said months ago, plus other additional complications. And then, being so unlike the rest of us, she just confronted my parents with it! I was out at the time and got a very worried phonecall telling me to come home, before being sat down and "told" that mummy and daddy are splitting up (but they still love me very much). It would've been funny if it wasn't so fucking awful. My dad made it clear it wasn't his decision, and made it seem like he was just being kicked out. If I didn't know him at all, maybe I would've bought that. It's been a couple of months since then and he's still here. You would think-- ah nevermind. This is what I've come to expect from my family. My parents anyway.

14 weeks on from my previous indecision, I start university tomorrow. I wonder what adventures await, what tales I will tell every so often to no-one in particular. It will probably be usual pattern: things are miserable...things are ok...things are awful...oh look I've quit. Roughly an 18 month cycle. Not to be pessimistic or anything, but it's a lot easier when you're prepared. But I'm kind of running out of career paths to do it for.

On another note, sorry to be predictable, but I hate Sarah Palin, and everything she stands for.

"Happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in it's own way." --Anna Karenina The last three months have been hell-like in some respects. Well, one respect. It's like someone overheard me saying I was ok with the whole divorce thing and decided to add a ton more complications and difficulties to really mess it up. And now I'm one of those people who says their ok about something when they're really not. What I was starting to think would never happen, happened - they talked. My mum told me he didn't think there was anything wrong (!) and he's happy with the way things are (!!). She couldn't quite believe this, but I suppose he doesn't understand what's changed - neither do I really. She doesn't want to see it, but it's clear to me he's still in love with her. When I thought they were both miserable and divorce would be best for them both it was so much easier - now it's going to hurt. Because he was so clueless about their situation my mum didn't feel able to tell him everything, he still think's there hope. So since then my dad has made a couple of utterly painful attempts at small talk with her in an attempt to fix things. That's the only difference there's been. Then there's the other thing. Despite the level of personal things I go into on here I can't quite do it on this one - there are a lot of other people involved. But basically it's made me see that things aren't as one-sided as I'd thought, that I've been extremely naive and that both my parents are emotionally-damaged, flawed individuals. But at some point I decided to try to stop resenting them for it, and learn from their mistakes. I have sworn to myself I will do everything possible to avoid being unhappy in the same way they are.

The status on my parents relationship is still critical. Valentine's Day was excrutiating. My dad left my mum a standard bunch of flowers and a card addressed "Mrs [my mum's maiden name]" on the envelope. Inside it was blank. Ouch. My mum got him a box of chocolates and threw out the card she'd got on seeing his, leaving instead a sombre black and white one of a dying tree branch. Nothing inside. Ouch again. I really thought this would trigger things off and went out so they could talk, but they seem to have ignored it, and 3 days on nothing's changed. I had the mad urge to write "DIVORCE?" across both of the cards - maybe that would move things along a little. It's getting quite frustrating. My naive, over-simplified view is that if you're miserable in a relationship, or anything really, do something about it. Don't just sit there watching things get worse. Whatever change you make is going to be difficult, but the sooner you do it the sooner you get through it, and things get better. But you have to make the first steps, and neither of them seems willing or able to. And if the empty gestures and the extreme tension on Thursday wasn't a catalyst for them I don't know what will be.

2008 ay? How did that happen? 2007 was a good year but it was getting old, so it's nice to have a change in the little number at the end of the date. My birthday, Hallowe'en, Fireworks night, Christmas and anything else that's happened since my last update were all standard, but enjoyable. New Year's was mildly disasterous but I enjoyed it anyway. I'm still at the same job, or a similar one in the same department. The work is of course dull, but not unbearable, and the people are nice - they say sorry before giving me all the worst jobs.

The other news I bring you is thus: according to the Family section of the Saturday Guardian today is "d-day" - the busiest time of year for divorces. Relevence? My parents are getting divorced. My dad doesn't know it yet, but it's happening. My mum and I have been having hushed discussions about it at various countryside locations, where she looks at me with pained expressions and tells me "I don't know what to tell you". The current situation is ridiculous - she doesn't want to do anything until the kitchen has been finished. The kitchen that was started 6 years ago, ground to a halt 5 1/2 years ago and hasn't been touched since. When she said that I thought neither were ever going to happen, then. I expect it'll get worse, but so far I think I'm taking it fairly well, but that doesn't mean I can stop thinking about it. I always assumed there was something I wasn't seeing in their relationship - they've been together for almost 30 years, afterall. Now I know there really, really isn't every interaction they have seems fake, forced and empty. I just want them to get on with it so we can all get on with our lives. I may have to start phoning kitchen people.

I've just been watching The Queen (the film) on ITV1 - "the Daily Mail of TV" according to my sister. "Interesting" I think is the word I'd use. As a staunch Labour and Tony Blair supporter with a diehard fascination/obsession with the Queen (the person) I was probably in a fairly unique position watching it, so here goes. Some of it was just completely ridiculous. One scene that stuck out was where the Queen was driving Charles about in a 4x4 around the Scottish countryside. Can the Queen even drive? I know she doesn't have to pass her test, but even if she had, is their any world where she would actually be allowed to drive herself, even ignoring that it's her and her son, the next in line to the throne, and a couple of weeks after Diana's crash? What if they'd crashed? And William, recently orphaned and having lost his grandmother within such a sort space of time, and still a teenager, was forced to become King? They're not even allowed on the same plane for goodness sake, let alone go galvanting round Scotland by themselves. And don't even get me started on when the Queen did it again, this time by herself, driving straight into a river and having to phone for help.

Another thing was the amount the Royal family watched TV - it was nearly as much as I do. Surely the Queen doesn't need to actually watch TV and read the tabloids directly to get her information? One of the many things that interest me about her is this detachment from all that - my view is that she'd be surrounded by so many advisors giving telling her these things - there would be several layers of people before such direct exposure to public events and reaction. How I would've done it would to be to show that - all these people around her, always sheltering her and protecting her, never able to get a moment alone because of them. I'd show her constantly having to do these events and meet carefully selected people, always being polite and respectful but not knowing them at all. And all those who will be having one of the most memorable days of their lives even catching a glimpse of her, but to her it's just a sea of unknown faces, and in reality they know as little about her as she does them. There were elements of that in the film, and to me they were the best parts. I loved the idea behind Tony's little tantrum about how she never chose to be Queen, and how she'd seen the job kill her father, but she dedicated her life to it and this country all the same.

Other hilariously stupid parts: Tony Blair acting like some schoolboy having been called into the headmistress' office when meeting her for the first time, awkward and unprepared next to the composed and suddenly very witty Queen. Cherie Blair constantly saying things like "off to meet your girlfriend", "all Labour prime ministers go soft around the Queen" etc. The Queen effectively predicting the Iraq war - very An Inspector Calls (don't even get me started on that one). The irritating stag metaphor - could it have been any more unsubtle? The way decisions seemed to be made mostly by Tony Blair, the Queen or both - as if either has that much power or control. Philip and the Queen sleeping in the same bed - it feels a bit weird knowing they sleep in separate rooms, but there you have it. Other good parts: Philip and the Queen mother were done well, and were funny too. Some of the stuff about modernising Vs the old traditions - the flag and all that, and the Royal family not understanding the need for change. Erm... Helen Mirren was good, but it was distracting as none of them actually looked like the people they were playing, so they were never entirely believable. Overall it wasn't *that* bad - it had it's moments, but to me it was like on of those dodgy straight-to-TV biopics they show on Channel 5 in the afternoon, rather than this Oscar-worthy depiction of the Royal family in the time around Diana's death.

Ok, rant over. Blame my mum - tried to rant about it to her but she said she didn't feel particularly strongly about it, shockingly. I think I'd annoyed her enough calling out " but the Queen doesn't have a license plate", "surely he would've been told the proper procedure weeks in advance", "what about (former HRH) Edward VIII's funeral?" etc etc all the way through. So I'll leave it there for today I think - was going to mention events in my own life but it'll have to wait. Try to contain yourselves.

I spent most of it talking to Peter, because everyone else was talking among themselves, and also because he was a new, interesting person. I love old people, I find everything they say fascinating, as long as it's not too, er, "conservative". He told me about his childhood, and being in the army, then his later life, and it was just so different from my life and anything I've ever experienced. It annoyed me slightly that everyone was treating him differently because they'd been told he was losing his memory - anything they said was almost embarassingly patronising. Most of the time he was absolutely fine - they were just going by what they'd been told and not actually taking the time to get to know him, and see for themselves. Seeing Leslie yesterday individually was equally fascinating, and I actually learnt a lot from him too. I think, after I get myself out of this rut of administrative work, I'd quite like to do some work in an old people's home, even if it's only temporarily. I would just like to take the time to listen to them, and make sure they're being looked after.

Not much else has happended this week - I did about 2 hours' work - still waiting to hear back from this woman about when to start my new job. My friends all have exams at the moment so I haven't seen much of them. Weird thought - this is the first May/June I haven't had exams for 11 years. This is a huge relief - I'm terrible with revision, usually starting about 2 hours before the exam. Which is ok, but those 2 hours are painfully stressful, and I always forget this and never change my ways. I am trying to do aome sort of learning occasionally, to prevent my brain from rotting entirely in case I ever want to use it again.

November is finally over, thank God. It is a truly horrible way to spend 1/12th of existence. The Novembers of 03, 04 and 06 have been undoubtedly the worst 3 months of my life, by far. I have dropped out of university.

I can't remember the last time I got to sleep before 4am. I'm not even sure if it is after 4am because of the whole time switching thing. I always forget what I've set back the night before and what sets itself back automatically, that is if I even remember the damn thing in the first place. So it could be 3:48am or 5:48am for all I know. Anyway, I thought at least I'd be getting an extra hour of sleep last night, only to be woken up by the bloody fire alarm. I leapt out of bed to get quickly dressed, thinking for a second I was still back in halls. The "fire" was supposedly coming from my room, so either I was burnt alive and am a ghost and don't know it, like in The Others, or there is something wrong with our smoke detectors. Either way I was in a bad mood for most of the day becuase of it. 2 of my housemates have gone home for 4 days and the other works weekends so I have been by myself for a considerable amount of the last 2 days. It has been both nice and horrible equally. My mum phoned this evening and I literally could not stop talking, just because it was some sort of human contact.

I am giving serious consideration to dropping out of university. Occasionally I feel a twinge of interest in Psychology, but it's not enough to motivate me to do the work, and I feel like it's making my condition worse. If you had some physical illness you wouldn't sit there focusing on it, seeing where it hurts and studying the pain. There was a time I though it would help me understand it, but I don't think that I ever will. And I don't think I'll ever recover from it either. It's been too long, too much damage has already been done. What's holding me back from just leaving is not having a clue what else I would do - sometimes I feel the urge to do something creative but know I have no talent whatsoever in any of those areas. I'm tied to this house until the end of June so can't go anywhere else - the only real option would be to get a job. A meaningless, repetitive, tedious, low-paying job - and that surely isn't a good idea. The book I'm currently reading told me "don't make decisions", which must have to be the worst advice ever. It's just not physically possible.

On a lighter note I am completely addicted to Pobol Y Cwm (a Welsh soap). I got hooked trying to find out a character's secret after seeing some of it accidently and now can't stop. I still don't know that secret and now 2 hours of my week are taken up watching the omnibus. Imogen made a cameo appearance the other week, speaking Welsh and everything, it was hilarious. Everyone who doesn't live in Wales is seriously missing out.

Bit of a weird birthday yesterday. After some consideration I decided to go home for it, and got back late on Thursday. Had a nice day on Friday, just me and my mum, then Eleanor came back on Saturday. We met her in London and went on the slides in the Tate Modern. It was packed, and stressful, and everyone was having endless discussions about whether it was art or not, but who cares when it's this much fun? In the evening we went out for a birthday meal, which was awful for several reasons. Eleanor actually walked out. In the evening she booked an earlier coach back to Cardiff and left at 9am on my actual birthday. I spent the day milling around at home, then spending 6 hours on various trains back to Bangor. It only really felt like my birthday when I was met at the station by my housemates, and we went back to the house where they'd decorated and made a cake, which was lovely. I cannot believe I am 2 decades old. I still feel (and look) about 14.

I have a confession to make: I have been unfaithful to my LJ. I started keeping a diary when I was on holiday, then stopped, then started again when I got back here. It's the only way I have of not forgetting 90% of things that happened any time before yesterday. So here is the other 10%.

Youth hostelling was great, I had more fun than I thought possible. I didn't work to pay for it, various family members kindly donated money for it (to be paid back). Turkey was also good - we went to Istanbul and some island with no cars, just horses and bikes. My dad loved it. Eleanor and I rode a donkeys up an enormous hill with a not-even-close-to-even road. We also went swimming a lot, though not in the sea as it was full of my greatest fear - jellyfish. And I can now say I've been to 4 continents before I'm 20 - we crossed over to the Asian side of Istanbul for a day.

Saw some friends and milled around at home for a week then ajourneyed back to uni. My mother decided to drop Eleanor and I off in one trip, ignoring the fact that we both were taking our entire belongings and there are no motorways in Wales. The trip to Cardiff was ok, though Eleanor felt sick throughout, and cried before and after we left. I was completely shocked by this - I can only remember seeing her cry once since she was a child. I did not cry when my mum left me in Bangor - tensions were high during the painful second part of the trip. She said some things that really angered me but I knew it wouldn't be wise to argue having no escape and no other way of getting there. She stayed the night at my house (which is about as nice as student accomodation gets, btw) then left.

So far it has been mixed. Things were very tight finacially for the first 2 weeks (before the loan came through) - if I hadn't brought food from home I would've starved. Our toilet was blocked for a while meaning we couldn't use it, shower or run water for 3 days. Our landlord is nice though, he gave us a week's free rent for it. I've been getting on with my housemates fine so far, no arguments as yet. And we have a TV (albeit one with bloody S4C destroying Channel 4) and the internet, which is a lot more than last year. Lectures are fine too, at the moment - there is a lot of work ahead but so far they've actually been fairly interesting.

And yet.. I feel awful. I could feel it coming towards the end of the summer but hoped it was just a phase/boredom and it would be better once I got back here. But it hasn't, just worse and worse and worse, and I have no-one I can talk to about it. I finally saw a doctor on Monday, foolishly forgetting how hopeless they are at anything to do with mental illness. I told her I wanted therapy, she gave me a prescription. Which shows that she's not taking me seriously and thinks I'm an idiot - I know it takes 4-6 weeks for this kind of medication to work. So, not knowing what else to do, I saw my new personal tutor, hoping she'd be able to help me academically at least. She told me she'd just recovered from the same thing and recommended a book, "Sunbathing in the Rain" by Gwyneth Lewis, which I've only just started but is absolutely brilliant. It was one of the most helpful discussions I've ever had about it, it was such a relief to be able to talk to someone who understands, and doesn't judge, and actually listens - it was exactly what I needed right then. Compare this with the conversation I had with my mum yesterday - I spoke her for the first time in 2 weeks needing help/support only to have her interrupting everything I tried to say with mundane work stories and a quiz night she went to described in excruciating detail.

It's going to be a long year. But aren't they all?

We randomly went to Paris yesterday. Why? Because my sister wrote on her personal statement that the Pompidou centre is her favourite building despite never having been there and my mum was worried they'd ask her about it if (when) she gets interviewed for Cambridge. It was good though. I thought I'd be in a bad mood all day after being forced out of bed at 6am (haven't seen that hour in a while!) then being dragged around art galleries and museums showing stuff I have no interest in, but really there was some amazing stuff, I have much more of an appreciation of art than before. Though some of it was just ridiculous, like huge canvases just painted one colour or just random spatters of paint (such cases of the Emporer's New Clothes). The other reason it was mostly good was because for once we actually went directly from place to place instead of meandering aimlessly and ending up nowhere which is enough to drive a person insane.
